Package org.opensextant.xtext

Class PathManager

  • java.lang.Object
    • org.opensextant.xtext.PathManager

  • public class PathManager
extends Object
    PathManager -- a group of routines related to caching conversions and archive collections. It manages the path decisions given a variety of output parameters and the input object.
    Author:
    ubaldino

    • Method Detail

      • enableSaving

        public void enableSaving​(boolean b)
        The overall flag to save converted output or not. DEFAULT: true = save it; provided caller specifies either saveWithInput or provides an archiveRoot
        Parameters:
        b - true to allow saving/caching conversions

      • isSaving

        public boolean isSaving​()

      • getConversionCache

        public String getConversionCache​()

      • setStripPrefixPath

        public void setStripPrefixPath​(String p)
        Set the prefix that will be removed from the leading part of paths as conversions are cached. Have a long, long file path? And want to shorten it in your cache... choose this prefix after thinking about it. If you strip too much you may end up with name conflicts or not enough organization to the cached stuff. NOTE: an error/warning is printed only if the prefix does not exist. This is not an exception or error, as you might get the paths to items from some other method and they may not actually exist physically on disk.
        Parameters:
        p - a prefix path that would be found in the absolute path of documents being converted.

      • getStipPrefixPath

        public String getStipPrefixPath​()

      • hasInputRoot

        public boolean hasInputRoot​()

      • setInputRoot

        public void setInputRoot​(File input)
                  throws IOException
        From the provided caching parameters set ahead of time, infer the location where this input should be located within the archive, relatively. This should only be set once at the top level, that is
        • if the call is to convert a single file, set it once for the file.
        • if the call is to convert a folder, set it once.
        • ... for archives, etc. set it once!
        Do not set it for each file when traversing a folder contents.
        NOTA BENE: Set conversion cache location first. 
           cache =  /output/converted/

   input =  /my/original/abc.zip  ==> /output/converted/abc_zip
   input =  /my/original/abc.doc  ==> /output/converted/abc.doc.txt
   input =  /my/original/abc/     ==> /output/converted/abc/


   prefix set, as prefix=/my

   input =  /my/original/abc.zip  ==> /output/converted/original/abc_zip
   input =  /my/original/abc.doc  ==> /output/converted/original/abc.doc.txt
   input =  /my/original/abc/     ==> /output/converted/original/abc/

  if saved-in-input, none of this applies.
        If you are caching conversions in an archive folder, A, then this generally sets your ouputNode to /A/name/ An items saved here will be of the form /A/name/relative/path For an input that came from /some/input/name/relative/path
        Parameters:
        input - root of your input which will be crawled
        Throws:
        IOException - if path does not exist or is not a directory

      • setConversionCache

        public void setConversionCache​(String root)
                        throws IOException
        This enables saving in an archive and disables saving with input.
        Parameters:
        root - container where conversions will be cached.
        Throws:
        IOException - on err
        See Also:
        enableSaveInCache(boolean), enableSaveWithInput(boolean)

      • enableSaveWithInput

        public void enableSaveWithInput​(boolean b)
        Save converted content with input. Xtext creates a new "xtext" folder in the containing folder of the current file. This is disabled if a non-null, pre-existing archive root is set. 
         input is:     a/b/c.doc
 saved as:     a/b/xtext/c.doc.txt
 
 DEFAULT: do not save in input folder
        Parameters:
        b - flag, true = save conversions close to given input
        See Also:
        setConversionCache(java.lang.String)

      • isSaveWithInput

        public boolean isSaveWithInput​()

      • enableSaveChildrenWithInput

        public void enableSaveChildrenWithInput​(boolean b)
        Experimental. ON by default. If you have email, for example, folder/A.eml then children will appear at folder/A_eml/child.doc for some child.doc attachment. Behavior may differ in each case. But essentially, this flag directs XText to write back to inputRoot Embedded parent/child docs (email, compound docs, etc) are special cases,
        Parameters:
        b - true if children objects should be extracted and save near input

      • enableSaveInCache

        public void enableSaveInCache​(boolean b)
        Saving to an archive specified by the caller; This is inferred if a non-null, pre-existing archive root is set; DEFAULT: do not save in archive. 
         input is:   a/b/c.doc
 output is:  archiveRoot/a/b/c.doc.txt
        Parameters:
        b - true if save in cache, not with input.
        See Also:
        setConversionCache(java.lang.String)

        public static String trimLeadingSlash​(String path)
        Caller is responsible for checking null.
        Parameters:
        path - a path
        Returns:
        trimmed path

      • getStrippedInputPath

        public String getStrippedInputPath​(File obj)
        Prepares a relative path, stripped of the prefix if one is provided. Otherwise, the input path is returned less a leading slash.
        Parameters:
        obj - a file.
        Returns:
        stripped path

      • fixPath

        protected static String fixPath​(String p)
        Most of the path mechanics are string-based, rather than file-system based, so path adjustments are best done to be sure all paths from configuration or from inputs should conform to a common convention. paths will be more like URLs, using "/" as the standard path separator. TODO: commons-io FilenameUtils.normalize() does not work quite right across platforms. Review, Retest.
        Parameters:
        p - path
        Returns:
        fixed path

      • createPath

        protected static String createPath​(String dir,
                                   String item)
                            throws IOException
        NOTE: Use of File() or FilenameUtils.concat() are OS dependent, here what we want is more like a URL string representation always using /a/b/c/ Instead of potentially \ and/or / mixed.
        Parameters:
        dir - containing dir
        item - item to save in subfolder
        Returns:
        path resulting path
        Throws:
        IOException - on err, e.g. permissions or disk full, etc.

      • getEmbeddedConversion

        public static ConvertedDocument getEmbeddedConversion​(File obj)
                                               throws IOException
        This provides some means for retrieving previously converted files. .... to avoid converted them.
        Parameters:
        obj - item to retrieve from cache
        Returns:
        doc ConvertedDocument from cache, otherwise null
        Throws:
        IOException - on err

      • getRelativePath

        public static String getRelativePath​(String root,
                                     String p)
        Given file /a/b/c.txt find me just the relative part to some root. That is, for example, if we care more about the b folder regardless of that it is physically located in /a. Perform:
        
 getRelativePath( "/a", "/a/b/c.txt") ===> b/c.txt
        Parameters:
        root - prefix path
        p - full path to an item.
        Returns:
        relative path wrt root

      • getCachedConversion

        public static ConvertedDocument getCachedConversion​(String cacheDir,
                                                    String inputDir,
                                                    File obj)
                                             throws IOException
        This provides some means for retrieving previously converted files. .... to avoid converted them. This method takes the arguments and tries to infer the actual location of a cached item. TODO: For compound documents this needs more work.
        Parameters:
        cacheDir - shadow dir or separate archive path
        inputDir - original input folder where this item came from
        obj - the requested file.
        Returns:
        the cached version of the conversion; null if not found or if no conversion was made.
        Throws:
        IOException - on err

      • makePath

        protected static String makePath​(File dir,
                                 String fname)
        Apache Commons file utils "concat(dir, file)" makes a mess of file names. Java can support "/" equally well on all platforms. there is no apparent need to use platform specific file separators in this context.
        Parameters:
        dir - containing dir
        fname - file name
        Returns:
        full path.

      • makePath

        protected static String makePath​(String dir,
                                 String fname)
        Apache Commons file utils "concat(dir, file)" makes a mess of file names. Java can support "/" equally well on all platforms. there is no apparent need to use platform specific file separators in this context.
        Parameters:
        dir - containing dir
        fname - file name
        Returns:
        full path.

      • isXTextCache

        public static final boolean isXTextCache​(String filepath)
        Simple test to see if filepath contains "./xtext/" for windows path or unix path.
        Parameters:
        filepath - path to test
        Returns:
        true if file parent is "/xtext/" or "\xtext\, case sensitive is found anywhere in path.

      • isXTextCache

        public static final boolean isXTextCache​(File obj)
        If a File is provided, this only checks the immediate parent folder.
        Parameters:
        obj - path to test.
        Returns:
        true if file parent is "xtext", case sensitive.
